 ABSTRACT The paper analyzes the impact of Chi:Le's Complementary Feeding Program (CFP), both on the direct and indirect beneficiaries. The paper describes Chile's major nutrition intervention programs and establishes the relative importance of the CFP in terms of budgetary expenditures and number of bene- ficiaries reached. It briefly reviews the program's past limitations, recent reforms and potential effectiveness. Finally, using data from the 1974-75 National Nutrition Survey, it examines whether participation by beneficiaries in the program was responsible for any significant difference in various indicators of nutritional wellbeing, once factors such as income, urban/rural location, sex and age are taken into account. - iii -

 FOOD DISTRIBUTION AND NUTRITION INTERVENTION: THE CASE OF CHIILE Chapter I: INTRODUCTION 1.01 Since 1924 Chile has distributed food to low-income households in order to improve the nutritional welfare of its people. The Complementary Feeding Program (CFP), one of five major foocl programs currently operating in Chile, is the most important in terms of cost: ($48 million in 1977) and number of benefic:Laries (more than 1.3 million). With its focus on supplement- lng the diets of preschool children (0-5 year olds), this program is believed to be targeted to the group where malnutrition is more prevalent and the potential effects of an inadequate diet more severe. While several studies have been done to determine the program-s participation rates, coverage, utilization by low-income households and cost-effectiveness, there Is only a limited amount of information on how successful the program has been in raising the nutritional status of the target population. Most studies have instead emphasized the potential, rather than the actual nutritional benefits that have resulted from the program. 1.02 Two major issues arise here: (1) to what extent is the food given to the household actually ingested by the intended beneficiary and (2) do the economic and dietary benefits induced by the program lead to a 'Long-term improvement of the nutritional status of the. population. Within these two issues there are a host of secondary issues: (i) the extent and incidence of malnutrition within specific regions, socioeconomic groups, and at different points in time; (ii) the major determinants of calorie and protein intake;
 - 2 - (iii) the importance of household behavior in determining intrafamily alloca- tion of food; and (iv) the most cost-effective delivery system for reaching those individuals who are malnourished. 1.03 The major purpose of this paper is to provide quantitative esti- mates of the impact of Chile's Complementary Feeding Program. The analysis presented is based upon data collected by the National Nutrition Survey of 1974 and upon budgeted expenditures on the CFP for selected years. Two methods of evaluating the impact of the program are used. The first method tests the hypothesis that the food given to the preschool child is treated as an income transfer. Using an age and sex specific calorie demand func- tion, the hypothesis can be tested that program participation increases nutrient intake over and above the increase generated by an equivalent income transfer. The results suggest that the program does result in a statistically significant increase in protein intake of young children (5-23) months of age) in addition to the effect of the parallel increase in the real income of the household. Furthermore, the direct effect appears to be larger (three to six times as much) than the income effect. While not significant at a high confidence level, a similar direct increase in calorie intake is also measured for the same age group of children. In the calorie case the direct increase is much larger than the income transfer increase, the ratio between the two ranging between 8 and 70 depending on the income of the participants. 1.04 The second method tests the hypothesis that the nutritional status of the population receiving the impact of the program is significantly different from the rest of the population, once factors such as income, urban/rural location, sex and age have been properly controlled. 1.05 The results of this test show that weight and height of participants are significantly different from the ones of non-participants for people between
 - 3 - 14 and 30 years of age. In addition to the income effect of the program, therefore, these results suggest that continued participation may have resulted in substantial long-term improvements of anthropometric characteristics. 1.06 The analysis performed also showed that demand for calories and proteins is significantly correlated to such factors as income, sex, urban/ rural location, family size, nutrition requirement (as specified in the Food and Agriculture Organization/World Heall:h Organization (FAO/WHO) standards and age and that the pattern of influence of these different variables tend to vary across the main meals. 1.07 The distribution of nutrients across members of the household appear to be skewed in favor of adult males only within the three main meals. When additional snacks are taken intD account, the results show that food allocation to family members closely conforms to nutritional requirements and tends to favor younger children. 1.08 The paper is divided into four other sections. Section I] describes Chile's major nutrition intervention programs and establishes the relative importance of the CFP in terms of budgetary expenditures and number of benefi- ciaries reached. Section III reviews the program-s past limitations, recent reforms and potential effectiveness. Section IV describes the 1974 National Nutrition Survey and summarizes the data from the Metropolitan Zone.. Based on these data, the major determinants of an individual's nutrient intalce, height and weight are estimated using multiple regression analysis. Section V then summarizes the three main conclusions emerging from this analysis.
 - 4 - Chapter II: NUTRITION INTERVENTION IN CHILE AND THE RELATIVE IMPORTANCE OF THE COMPLEMENTARY FEEDING PROGRAM 2.01 Chile is similar to other Latin American countries in that it has had extensive experience with nutrition intervention programs. Since 1924 it has distributed milk to children and pregnant and lactating mothers. More recently, its efforts include the establishment of nutrition centers to rehabilitate severely malnourished children, the provision of breakfasts and lunches through the school lunch program and the distribution of a monthly food allotment to low-income households via its Minimum Employment Program. These activities taken together cost approximately US$80 million per year, of which US$9.8 million comes from foreign contributions, thus accounting for approximately 10.5% of total government expenditures on social welfare--US$756.3 million (see Table 1). 2.02 As shown in Table 2, of the five major nutrition programs cur- rently operating in Chile, the Complementary Feeding Program (CFP) is the most important, both in terms of cost and number of beneficiaries reached. Without any explicit eligibility criterion, this program serves approxi- mately 81% of all children up to the age of 5 and nearly all pregnant and lactating women. Under this program, a different type and amount of food is provided to each group differentiated according to age. Children between O and 2 years receive whole milk (2-3 kg per month) which has been fortified with iron and vitamin C. Older children, 2-5 years of age, receive a special protein-enriched formula (Fortesan) containing soy and wheat flours in addition to powdered milk (1.5 kg per month). 2.03 While the CFP is still Chile's predominate nutrition interven- tion activity, the government has attempted to scale down the program and

Simultaneously, it is attempting to focus more attention on the severely malnourished child and on changing the environment which creates malnutri- tion. Over the next five years, the government plans to make three major changes to its nutrition programs: (i) the construction of 14 additional nutrition rehabilitation centers with a capacity to care for 2,142 severely malnourished children per year (26 centers already exist); (ii) expansion of its nursery school program with increased emphasis on children who live in extreme poverty and suffer some degree of malnutrition and whose fathers are alcoholics or unemployed; and (iii) by 1982 to extend the School Lunch Program to over 75% of the children between 6 and 16. 2.04 These changes do not seem particularly dramatic until they are put in terms of their implications as to the percent of the target popula- tion reached by each of these programs and the potential costs to the govern- ment. The 26 existing nutrition rehabilitation centers, for example, currently have the capacity to care for approximately 4,000 children per year. With the 14 new centers, this program can potentially rehabilitate 6,142 severely malnourished children per year. According to data collected by the National Health Service (SNS) clinics, covering approximately 80% of Chile's population, less than 0.5% of all children under the age of five are severely malnourished (below 80% of reference weight for age). When these figures are expanded to represent the entire group, they suggest that approximately 7,000 children are severely malnourished (1977). Therefore, the
 newly-expanded system should have the capacity to reach nearly 9 out 10 third-degree children. Given that it costs approximately $5 per day and takes less than 5 months to rehabilitate a child, the annual operating costs of this program, assuming no decline in the stock of third-degrees, will be about $4.5 million, or nearly two and one-half times that budgeted in 1977. 2.05 The planned expansion of the nursery school program with its focus on low-income households also reflects Chile's increased fiscal com- mitment to nutrition-related activities. Since 1970, with the establish- ment of the National Council of Nursery Schools (Junta Nacional de Jardines Infantiles--JNJI), the number of nursery schools operating in urban areas has increased from 56 (4,000 children) to 461 (50,000 children) in 1978. Although the government originally intended to extend the program to all preschoolers, this proved too ambitious, given fiscal constraints. Conse- quently, the government has redefined its objectives and plans to place greater emphasis on the needs of the most disadvantaged (approximately 150,000). This threefold increase implies a program costing approximately $14.0 million. 2.06 By far the most costly and ambitious proposal is the expansion of the School Lunch Program. Given resources currently available, it is con- sidered impossible to extend the meal program to all children enrolled in school. Instead, a survey has been undertaken to determine where the greatest proportion of children are malnourished in order to target the program by school. Within 5 years, there are plans to extend the program to 75% of the school population (1.7 million). Therefore, approximately 280,000 new beneficiaries would have to be brought into the program each year. Given that it costs between 36 and 45 cents/ration (800 calories or one-third of the child's requirement) and assuming that each child is fed
 - 9 - 180 days, the cost of the program would increase by $20.4 million each year. Taken together, these changes suggest: that Chile s expenditures on its nutrition intervention programs would have to increase to roughly $200 million in real terms by 1982, an increase of nearly 20% per year between 1977 and 1982. This rate of increase is un:Likely, given historical rates unless of course external assistance is increased significantly or other existing programs cut back. Accepting that these intentions may not be realized, are Chile's current activities effective, and can we reasonably expect any benefits from continuing and possibly greatly expanded programs in this area? 2.07 Given the fact that the Complementary Feeding Program currently accounts for the largest percent of budgeted expenditures and the fact that it is the only program for which data are readily available, the remainder of this paper focuses on the effectiveness and potential benefits from this particular program. Although it would be more desirable to evaluate the other programs where expansion is envisioned, this is left for future analysis.
 - 10 - Chapter III: PAST PROBLEMS, RECENT REFORMS, AND POTENTIAL EFFECTIVENESS OF THE PROGRAM 3.01 Since the early 1970s the CFP has undergone a series of changes. For the most part, these reforms have been an outgrowth of a curtailment in foreign assistance and have had little to do with an explicit decision whether or not the actual benefits from supplemental feeding justified its costs. Due to the high foreign exchange costs following the curtailment of Public Law 480 shipments of milk in the early 1970s, the government ini- tiated research into the development of an acceptable locally produced sub- stitute. Efforts were also made to reduce the program's costs by targeting the program only to children'under the age of five. 3.02 Studies in the United States and Latin America have indicated that targeted food programs are likely to be ineffective for two reasons: (i) limited and irregular participation in these programs by the neediest groups; and (ii) the fact that children participating in the feeding programs receive less food at home. 1/ The Complementary Feeding Program, however, is an exception. Studies indicate that participation in the program by low-income households is relatively high. In theory, every malnourished child under the age of six should be covered by the program, since, by national law, all children in this age group are entitled to a free ration of milk. Unlike other SNS health programs where access has been limited due to inadequate capacity and strict eligibility criteria (the need to prove indigence), prenatal, postnatal, and infant care, in addition to milk distribution through the SNS clinics has generally been available. In a recent survey of low-income households served by the SNS in the Santiago metropolitan area, over 96% of the eligible population was found t:o be receiving the prescribed milk allottment.l/ This finding is supported by two earlier studies which found between 75 and 78% 2/ of those eligible parti- cipating. Both studies also concluded that more than 75% of participating household secured the allotted quantities of milk for all beneficiaries in the family, and that nearly 90% of these households obtained milk on a regular basis. 3.03 Even though the program may be reaching preschool children that are at nutritional risk, it is questionable whether the food supplement given under the program actually improves the child's nutritional status. It is believed that actions taken by the National Food and Nutritional Council (CONPAN) to acidify the milk and to educate the family as to the importance of the food being given to the child has reduced intrafamily leakages. According to research by the SNS, this has resulted in the children receiving over 80% of the milk provided. Nevertheless, whether this increase in milk intake (food supplement) actually results in a net increase in nutrient intake is still an issue. Even if the child were to receive all of the supplement, it is still possible for the mother to merely reduce the amount of food normally given to the child. What ultimately happens when supplementation occurs is believed to depend on how the family perceives the food that is distributed by the government. If the supplement is seen as an increase in food for the household and not as a necessary addition to a child's diet, then the likelihood that substitution will occur is increased. 3.04 Without data on an individual child's nutritional status both before and after supplementation, it is impossible to directly estimate the impact of this type of food distribution program. Because this information is not available, two indirect methods, both based on multiple regression analysis, will be used in this study. The first method consists of estimat- ing calorie demand functions, by meal, while the second method is based on the estimation of functions that relate individual weight and height to program participation, age, income, sex, family size and location. The data for performing both of these analyses of CFP impact is taken from the National Nutrition Survey of 1974/75.

INCIDENCE AND SEVERITY OF MALNIJTRITION IN CHILE: SOME RESULTS FROM THE 1974 NATIONAL NUTRITION SURVEY 4.01 Chile is not a food-deficit country in the sense of many Asian or African countries. Calorie availability per capita (2,734 calorie/capita/day in 1972-74) is well above average per capita requirements (2,400 calorie/day). 1/ The problem is instead one of distribution both between households in different income groups and between the individual members of the family. Three studies one done in 1933 under the auspices of the League of Nations, a secon,l done in 1960 by the Interdepartmental Committee on Nutrition for National Defense (ICNND), and a third in 1968-69 by the Chilean National. Institute of Statistics provide information on the distribution of calorie consumption by income class. According to these studies, food consumption among Chile's low-income groups did not increase by any significant degree between 1935 and 1970. In addition, approximately one- third of the households were consistently consuming less than the amount of calories necessary to meet the family's overall requirement. 2/ BeccLuse these past studies referenced the household as the basic unit of measurement and not the individual, they were unable to assess the incidence of malnutrition or, simply stated, the degree to which specific individual members of a Family or of different age and sex categories suffer nutritional deprivation. 4.02 The analysis presented in this section is based upon data collected by the National Nutrition Survey of 1974/75. 3/ This survey is unique in that it is 1/ United Nations - FAO, Provisional Food Balance Sheets, 1972-74 Average, Rome 1977. 2/ Fernando Monckeberg, Food and Nutrition Policy in Chile, National Food and Nutrition Council, 1977. 3/ Ministry of Health,Survey of Nutritional Condition of the Population of Chile, July 1974-June 1975: Initial Report (Spanish), Santiago, March 1976.

Description of the Survey 4.03 The 1974 National Nutrition Survey was carried out between June 1974 and June 1975 through the Nutrition Division of the Directorate-General of the National Health Service. The sample collected information from urban and rural areas in four major geographic areas. North Planning Zone (provinces from Tarapaca to Coquimbo); Metropolitan Planning Zone (provinces from Aconcagua to Colchagua); Center-South Planning Zone (provinces from Curico to Malleco); and South Planning Zone (provinces from Cautin to Magallanes). Information was collected in five general areas: socioeconomic, anthropometric, clinical, dietetic, and biochemical. Approximately 4,800 households were surveyed for data in the first three areas while a smaller subsample of 1,600 households was used to collect additional information on dietetic patterns and biochemical data. 4.04 As can be seen in Table 3, the number of households selected within each region is inconsistent with previous census estimates of the population living in each of these four macro-zones.  - 36 - Chapter V: CONCLUSIONS 5.01 The results presented in this paper are partial and tentative. The sample of observations considered covers only the metropolitan area of Santiago: an important part, but still only half of the total population of Chile. The same sample is based on a survey conducted for a particular year, so that any conclusion as to the relationship of the results for that year to the previous and following years is necessarily speculative. Many observations, particularly on individual family meals, are missing and, while there is no evidence of a bias, our information is not sufficient to exclude some systematicism in the missing observations. Finally, the nature of the statistical evidence revealed is more negative than positive and is limited to a very specific set of tests and a handful of estimated parameters. 5.02 Nevertheless, after having taken into account and underlined these inherent weaknesses of our data, data treatment and results, there remain a number of interesting and in part startling conclusions which are worth summarizing and briefly illustrating here. First, a popular functional form of a demand equation for nutrients appears to explain well the inter- individual differences in calorie and protein consumption. (But the statistical tests conducted are unable to reject the hypothesis that program participation has an effect on household calorie consumption equivalent to a cash transfer or increase in real income, on all family members except the smaller children (5-23 months old). Estimates of this equation reveal a measurable though statistically significant at rather low levels of confidence, increase in calorie consumption and a highly significant increase in protein consumption by children (5-23 months) in the participant group. These increases are over and above the ones that can be predicted on the basis of socioeconomic and growth differences.
 - 37 - 5.03 Second, the data support the popular presumption that males adults of working age have the lion's share of "formal." family meals (breakfast, lunch and dinner) and that female members and/or children of younger age are com- paratively at disadvantage in these major meals. However, when account is taken of snacks and other sources of nutrients, the distribution of nutrients among household members appear to follow quite strictly their need as expressed by FAO/WHO requirement and no significant sex or age bias;es emerges. Moreover, such an egalitarian distribution of basic food among the members of the household tends to reinforce the result obtained on program participation effect. 5.04 Third, the analysis of weight and height measurements of the individuals belonging to the two population groups supports the hypothesis that these two vital statistics are determined by (i) genetic factors, (ii) family income, and (iii) other socioeconomic variables. The same analysis also suggests that a long-term effect of program participation may have taken place as shown in a significant difference in weight and height measurements of population members in a critical age group (14-30 years). This age group is critical from the point of view of the individual growth curve, i.e., substantial increases in dietary intakes t:hroughout infancy and early adolescence are likely to show their impact during the puberty/young adulthood period.

The impact of a supplementary food program would ideally be studied by an experiment appropriately designed to control all socioeconomic and genetic factors that might cause differences in food intakes and vital statistics between participants and nonparticipants. In practice, even if experiments can be designed to measure specific, short-term effects of the program, it would be impossible to design and carry out a plan of measure- ments over a long period of time and simultaneously maintain some of the basic features of experimental design such as, for example, the random assignment of subjects to the two groups to be compared. 2. Rather than by an experiment, program impact can be measured by taking proper account of the individual variables that would be controlled through careful experimental design. This can be accomplished through the use of a quantitative model, where the effects of variables other than program participation are estimated and accounted for separately. While models of various sophistication can be used, their ultimate objective with regard to program impact measurement is simply to separate the source of variation due to program participation from the one due to outside factors. Once the program effect is isolated from the one of other potentially con- fusing variables, questions can be asked not only as to the statistical significance of the effects generated by the program, but also as to the estimate of their direct and indirect impacts on the target population. 3. doc.repnme: Food distribution and nutrition intervention; the case of Chile
doc.abstracts: The paper analyzes the impact of Chile's Complementary Feeding Program (CFP), both on the direct and indirect beneficiaries. The paper describes Chile's major nutrition intervention programs and establishes the relative importance of the CFP in terms of budgetary expenditures and number of beneficiaries reached. It briefly reviews the program's past limitations, recent reforms and potential effectiveness. Finally, using data from the 1974-75 National Nutrition Survey, it examines whether participation by beneficiaries in the program was responsible for any significant difference in various indicators of nutritional wellbeing, once factors such as income, urban/rural location, sex and age are taken into account. The major purpose of this paper is to provide quantitative estimates of the impact of Chile's Complementary Feeding Program.
